origination.corpname: University of Michigan. Provost and Executive Vice-President for Academic Affairs.

did.abstract: Central academic administrative unit of the University of Michigan which functions as chief executive assistant to the president, responsible for appointments and promotions with oversight for schools, colleges, educational units and programs; including budget planning, legislative relations, institutional research, and affirmative action policies. The Staff Files subgroup contains the files of individual of vice-presidents, associate and assistant vice-presidents, and other staff members within the vice-president's office.
did.physloc: Portions of the records are stored offsite. Two days notice required for retrieval.

acqinfo.p: The Provost's Office (Donor No. 5120) makes periodic additions to the records. Records were first received in 1971.

accessrestrict.p: Access to parts of the VPAA record group is restricted based on applicable law and university policy. Restricted material includes personnel files, search files, tenure and review files, grievance and disciplinary files and student files. In addition, the VPAA records are subject to these restrictions

list.item: Files of a vice president, or a member of his/her staff, still in office, are restricted.

Files of a vice president or a member of his/her staff, no longer in office, are restricted for ten years from the date of their origin. Files over ten years old are open. This restriction applies to files added to the record group prior to January 1, 2000.

Files added to the record group after January 1, 2000 are restricted for twenty years from the date they were added to the record group, in accord with the access policy for executive officer level records as described below. The VPAA record group does not, as yet, include any records in this category.

p.emph: Access Restrictions for University of Michigan Records

blockquote.p: University records are public records and once fully processed are generally open to research use. Records that contain personally identifiable information will be restricted in order to protect individual privacy. Certain administrative records are restricted in accordance with university policy as outlined below. The restriction of university records is subject to compliance with applicable laws, including the Michigan Freedom of Information Act.

Categories of Restricted Records
Personnel-related files, including search, review, promotion, and tenure files, are restricted for thirty (30) years from the date of their creation.
Student educational records: FERPA's protection of personally identifiable information in a student's education records ends at the time of a student's death and therefore is a matter of institutional policy. As a courtesy to the families of recently deceased students who were enrolled at the time of death, the University generally will not release information from their education records for five years without the consent of the deceased student's next of kin. Eighty-five (85) years after the date the records were first created, the University will presume that the student is deceased. Thereafter the student's education records will be open. Student records at the Bentley Historical Library are restricted for eighty-five (85) years, but may also be made available upon proof of the death of the student.
Patient/client records are restricted for one-hundred (100) years from the date of their creation. The terms of use for particular records older than 100 years may require the research to sign a Patient/Client Access Agreement.
Executive records: Records generated by the university's executive officers, deans, directors, department heads, and their designated support staff are restricted for twenty (20) years from the date of their creation.
Restricted files are indicated in the contents list of the collectionâ€™s finding aid with a restriction note indicating the restriction type and the date of expiration.

For further information on the restriction policy and placing Freedom of Information Act requests for restricted material, consult the reference archivist at the Bentley Historical Library (bentley.ref@umich.edu) or the University of Michigan Freedom of Information Office website (https://foia.vpcomm.umich.edu/).

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan but the collection may contain third-party materials for which copyright is not held. Patrons are responsible for determining the appropriate use or reuse of materials.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Provost and Executive Vice-President for Academic Affairs (University of Michigan). Staff Files, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: As of 1995 the office represented by this record group is officially titled the Office of the Provost and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs. Previous titles of the office were: Vice Presidents for Academic Affairs and Provost, 1983-1995; Vice President for Academic Affairs, 1962-1983; and Provost, 1938-1962.

The origins of this office date back to 1938, during President Ruthven's administration, when the position of provost was created by a bylaw of the Board of Regents to "aid the President by performing such of the President's functions as shall from time to time be delegated by him or by the Board of Regents" (Regents' Proceedings, March 1938, p. 505). E. Blythe Stason, the dean of the Law School who had already been performing many of these functions, was appointed the first provost. Stason resigned as provost in November 1944 to devote his attentions to the leadership of the Law School, and James P. Adams, vice president of Brown University and former University of Michigan economics professor, assumed the post of provost and professor of economics in January 1945. At the Regents' meeting of January 1945 the bylaw establishing the provost's position was amended to include the statement that the provost "shall be the chief executive officer of the University next to the President" (Regents' Bylaw 2.02). Adams remained the provost until his resignation in July 1951. A successor to Adams was not named, and the responsibilities of the provost were absorbed by the newly created vice president and dean of faculties, Marvin Niehuss.
In 1962 two new positions were created in the university administration: executive vice president and vice president for academic affairs.

Marvin Niehuss, vice president for university relations since 1945 and the vice president and dean of faculties since 1951, was promoted to the position of executive vice president in 1962. As vice president and dean of faculties, Niehuss had coordinated university relations with the state legislature and had overseen the administration of the schools, colleges, and other units (including institutes, Extension Service, summer session, and the Reserve Officers' Training Corps), reporting on enrollment, teaching loads, research, and faculty salaries. In his new position as executive vice president, Niehuss continued to supervise legislative relations and served as the University's contact with the state board of education. In addition, the executive vice president was the chief executive assistant to the president and assumed the duties and powers of the president in his absence. (When Niehuss retired in 1968 the position of executive vice president was abolished and a vice president for state relations and planning was established in its place.)

Roger Heyns, a member of the Psychology Department and since 1959 dean of the College of Literature, Science and the Arts, was appointed to the position of vice president for academic affairs in 1962. Heyns assumed many of the duties previously performed by the vice president and dean of faculties. He was given general executive responsibility for the faculty and for the academic programs of the schools, colleges, and other educational units. He reviewed recommendations of deans, directors, and department heads with regard to appointments, promotions, leaves of absence, and salaries of faculty members and special service personnel. In addition, the Offices of Admissions, and Registration and Records--previously under the jurisdiction of the vice president for student affairs--were brought under the vice president for academic affairs.

This reorganization of administrative responsibilities was intended as a means of unifying planning in a period of rapid growth of the University. In actual practice, the duties associated with planning remained dispersed and were shifted from one office to another in the 1960s and 1970s. When a vice presidency for state relations and planning was established in 1968, some of the responsibility for academic program planning was transferred to that office. The Office of Institutional Research, which collected and analyzed data on enrollment trends, faculty characteristics, funding, and related subjects, was transferred in 1969 from Academic Affairs to State Relations and Planning. In 1974 the Office of Institutional Research was renamed the Office of Academic Planning and Analysis and was returned to Academic Affairs, reflecting the assignment of additional evaluation and planning responsibilities under the vice president for academic affairs. Over the course of the 1960s and 1970s, the vice president for academic affairs gradually assumed greater responsibility for budget preparation.

In addition to program and budget planning, the Office of Academic Affairs was involved in implementing affirmative action plans, overseeing the Opportunity Program and Tuskegee-Michigan exchange program, and coordinating support services for minority students.

When Roger Heyns left the university in 1965 to become chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, he was succeeded by Allan F. Smith, the dean of the Law School. Smith held the post of vice president for academic affairs for nine years and in 1974 was followed by Frank H. T. Rhodes, a professor of geology and since 1971 dean of the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts. Rhodes resigned in 1977 to assume the presidency of Cornell University.

Harold T. Shapiro, chairman of the Economics Department, was appointed vice president for academic affairs in 1977 and held the position until 1980, when he became president of the University of Michigan. Alfred Sussman, dean of Rackham School of Graduate Studies, served as acting vice president for academic affairs from November 1, 1979 through July 1, 1980, when Billy E. Frye, professor of Zoology and dean of the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, assumed the position.

p.emph: Vice President for Academic Affairs and Provost

bioghist.p: At its February 1983 meeting, the Regents of the University of Michigan changed the title of the position to Vice President for Academic Affairs and Provost (hereafter referred to as "provost"). The move to include "provost" in the title was taken in part because of the increased responsibility of the vice president within the university's administration and because of the need to assist the president as he moved into state and national projects, notably the management of the capital campaign fund-raising effort.

In 1986, Billy E. Frye resigned and was replaced by James J. Duderstadt, dean of the College of Engineering, who served as provost until he became the president of the university in September 1988. Robert Holbrook served as interim provost until December 1988. In January 1989, Charles Vest, dean of the College of Engineering, became provost and remained until July 1990, when he left to assume the presidency of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Holbrook served as interim provost for the month of August, after which Gilbert Whitaker, dean of the School of Business Administration, began his tenure as provost.

p.emph: Provost and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs

bioghist.p: In September 1993 the Regents approved a change in title to provost and executive vice president for academic affairs. This title was intended to reflect more accurately the responsibilities of the provost and to "bring Michigan into line with the administrative structures of other universities" (The University Record 49(3), 1993 September 20: 4). The new designation came about when President Duderstadt recommended a change in title for Whitaker. In 1995 Whitaker returned to teaching and was succeeded by J. Bernard Machen, dean of the School of Dentistry. Machen initially served on an interim basis before agreeing to accept a two-year appointment. He did not seek an extension and was succeeded by Nancy Cantor, dean of the Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies in 1997.

The position vice provost for academic affairs was created in 1990 to recognize university-wide activities in which John H. D'Arms, dean of Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies, was engaged that were beyond the scope of his decanal responsibilities. Such responsibilities included overseeing the Bentley Historical Library and the Clements Library, evaluating promotion and tenure dossiers, and serving as liaison between the university and major foundations (The University Record 45(24), 1990 March 26: 1). With the appointment of new provosts the functional responsibilities and reporting relationships of the vice provost have frequently changed.

arrangement.head: Summary Box Listing
arrangement.p: The records of the Provost and Executive Vice-President for Academic Affairs are organized into three subgroups: Central Files, Staff Files, and Supplemental Files. Each of the subgroups is described in a separate finding aid. The Staff Files subgroup is organized in series for individual staff members. The series may include subseries of Chronological Files, Topical Files, Schools and Colleges and occasionally other files. The records of an individual staff member were often received in a number of separate accessions. For this finding aid, all the files of a staff member have been brought together to reflect the intellectual organization of the records rather than their physical arrangement in boxes. As a consequence, the box numbers may not be in numerical order.

scopecontent.p: The Staff Files subgroup of the record group Provost and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs consists of 570 linear feet and spans the years from 1947 to 2013. The Staff Files subgroup is comprised of the records of the associate and assistant vice presidents for academic affairs. Whereas the records of the Central Files subgroup often contain finished products, such as reports and policy statements, the Staff Files subgroup tends to document the process of policy formation and other decision-making functions. Scattered through the associate and assistant vice presidents' papers, for example, are frank statements of opinion regarding various schools and programs, candidates for promotion, and the relationship between the branches of the university, as well as notes on meetings with faculty members, committee activities, and other subjects.

The Staff Files subgroup includes the records of the following past and current associate and assistant vice presidents, listed in the order in which their records first appear in the boxlist: Ernest R. Zimmermann, Carolyne K. Davis, Edward A. Dougherty, Richard A. English, Robert L. Williams, John H. Romani, Mary Ann Swain, Robert S. Holbrook, W. Allen Spivey, Robert B. Holmes, Niara Sudarkasa, Robin Jacoby, Robert Sauve, E. Kay Dawson, Susan Lipschutz, Paul Courant, Marilyn Knepp, Pamela A. Raymond, Katharine Soper, Karen Gibbons, John Godfrey, Nancy Cantor, A. Lawrence Fincher, Ralph P. Pollack, Lori Haskins, and Ron Fitzgerald. The records of an individual, while still in office, are received by the archives on an ongoing basis.

scopecontent.p: The records of Ernest R. Zimmermann (1.2 linear ft.), assistant to the vice president in the area of academic services from 1965 to 1981/82, consist of a wide variety of committee files dating from 1960 to 1981. The files arranged in two separate alphabetical listings. Among them are the staff meeting minutes of the Office of Academic Affairs for 1974 to 1979.

scopecontent.p: The records of Carolyne K. Davis document both the wide range of her responsibilities as associate vice president as well as her professional interests and activities outside of the university, particularly in the areas of nursing, health sciences, and women's issues. Davis succeeded John Romani as associate vice president for academic affairs in 1975. She had been dean of the School of Nursing since 1973. Her files include some materials dating as far back as 1967 but are primarily from the years 1975 to 1981, at which time she resigned her post as associate vice president to accept a position with the Department of Health and Human Services in Washington, D.C.

Davis's records are divided into three subseries: Topical Files; Schools and Colleges Files; and Legislative Files. The Topical Files and the Schools and Colleges Files contain correspondence, reports, reviews, and budget planning materials regarding the many units that were under Davis's jurisdiction. The Topical Files are also a strong source of information regarding Davis's participation in professional organizations. The Legislative Files series contains information on the University's relations with Congress and the Michigan legislature from 1977 to 1980, primarily with regard to budget appropriations and federal regulation activities in the areas of health sciences and nursing.

scopecontent.p: The records of Edward A. Dougherty, assistant to the vice president for academic affairs from 1974/75 until 1981/82, consist of two subseries: Topical Files; and Schools and Colleges, Search and Review Files. The latter comprises the bulk of his records. The Topical Files are limited to committee materials and cover three topics from 1977 to 1982: the China Task Force, the Subcommittee on the Organization of the Medical Complex, and the Periodic Health Appraisal Unit (PHAU) Advisory Committee. The Schools and Colleges, Search and Review Files document the process of selection and hiring of deans, directors, department heads, and administrators as well as internal and external reviews of the programs of various schools and colleges in the period 1971/72 to 1981/82. Because of their confidential nature, material regarding searches for or evaluations of unit heads have been moved and are restricted for thirty years from their date of creation.

scopecontent.p: The records of Richard A. English (7 linear ft.) consist of one series: Topical Files, 1972-1979. English served as associate vice president for academic affairs from 1974 until 1981, when he resigned to return to his academic position in the School of Social Work. English's responsibilities for coordination of the academic service units and minority student support services are well documented, as is his involvement with the Graduate Employees Organization (GEO) and the Netherlands Visiting Professorship. In addition, there are a number of folders regarding the Evaluation and Planning Project, undertaken from 1975 to 1977. The purpose of the project was to promote units' systematic planning of program changes, enrollment, and affirmative action.

scopecontent.p: The records of Robert L. Williams (11.5 linear ft.), who served as administrative dean in the Office of Academic Affairs from 1962 to 1974, consist of one subseries: Topical Files, 1950-1974. Prior to becoming administrative dean, Williams was assistant dean of faculties from 1951 until 1962, assistant to the provost from 1945 to 1951, and assistant registrar from 1936 to 1945. The files include materials from Williams's tenure as administrative dean as well as from his tenure as assistant dean of faculties. The records also contain information on the early years of the Office of Academic Affairs and its predecessor offices. As administrative dean, Williams assisted in formulating academic plans and policies and oversaw special studies.

The majority of Williams's records reflect his involvement with committees and organizations dedicated to communication and cooperation among institutions of higher education both within the state of Michigan and among the universities comprising the Big Ten. In addition, Williams's files contain a large amount of material regarding the Reserve Officers' Training Corps (ROTC) on campus in the 1960s and 1970s. For further information regarding Robert Williams's career, researchers should see a small collection of his papers that is cataloged separately.

scopecontent.p: The files of John H. Romani, associate vice president for academic affairs from 1971 to 1974, consist of one subseries of Topical Files, 1955-1977 (ca. 12 linear feet). Romani was a professor and associate dean in the School of Public Health before becoming associate vice president for academic affairs. As associate vice president he was responsible for coordinating international programs, the Opportunity Program, and the faculty-student exchange with Tuskegee Institute as well as overseeing academic service activities, including admissions, financial aid, orientation, registration and records, scheduling, and evaluation and examination. In addition, he represented Vice President Smith on Division of Health Sciences committees.

Topics with extensive documentation in Romani's files include Committees (mostly health-related), Office of Financial Aid, Ford Foundation Grants, Opportunity Program, Search and Review Committees (mostly health-related), and the University Center for Adult Education. The Ford Foundation Grants subseries document the university's use of two grants given by the Ford Foundation in 1961 and 1966 totaling 7.5 million dollars for teaching and research on the non-Western world. Additional documentation of the Ford Foundation grants is located in the Supplemental Files subgroup.

scopecontent.p: Mary Ann Swain, professor of nursing research in the School of Nursing, was appointed associate vice president for academic affairs in 1983. Swain's files (about 62 lin. ft.) cover the years 1970 to 1993 and consist of a number of series, many of which are recurring, reflecting the various accessions in which the materials were received: Budget Priorities Committee, Topical Files, Chronological Files, Schools and Colleges Files (both budget and nonbudget), Units Files (both budget and nonbudget), Reserve Officers' Training Corps (ROTC), and Retreats. As the topics and the dates for each series tend to overlap, the researcher is advised to search more than one series for information on a given topic. Also, because Swain and Robert S. Holbrook have, at times, exchanged areas of responsibility, the researcher should review the records of both staff members for material on a given topic or university unit.

Dr. Swain had a wide-ranging background in university affairs. In addition to her service in the School of Nursing, she served on a variety of university committees, including the Committee on the Status of Women in Higher Education, which she chaired in 1977-78, and the Budget Priorities Committee which she chaired from 1981 to 1983. Beginning in 1983, Dr. Swain served as associate vice president for academic affairs. In this position, she assumed responsibility for various administrative matters pertaining to faculty affairs, the operating needs of the schools and colleges, and academic services. She also had direct line administrative and fiscal responsibility for a number of institutes and centers, such as the Center for Continuing Education of Women, special libraries and museums.

She assumed primary responsibility for administration of the Target of Opportunity (TOO) program which increased the number of minority faculty on campus. Additionally, she worked with academic units on the implementation of policies regarding the disabled, and she chaired the task force which drafted the staff and faculty policy on sexual and racial harassment.

scopecontent.p: Robert S. Holbrook served as associate vice president from 1981 to 1993, when his title was changed to associate provost. His appointment in the provost's office ended in 1997 and he returned to teaching in the Department of Economics. He attained emeritus status in 2000. He originally joined the faculty in 1965, was promoted to professor in 1975 and served as an associate dean in the College of Literature, Science and the Arts from 1978 to 1981. His records (156 lin. ft.) date from 1979 to 1997, and consist of a number of series, many of which are recurring: Topical Files, Chronological Files, Schools, Colleges and Units Files (both Budget and Nonbudget), Personal Files, Strategic Planning Files, Value Centered Management, and Office of Budget and Planning--Glenna Schweitzer.

As the topics and the dates for each series tend to overlap, the researcher is advised to search more than one series on a given topic. Also, because Holbrook and Mary Ann Swain have, at times, exchanged areas of responsibility, the researcher should review the records of both staff members on a given topic. At the end of his career, Holbrook's duties were undertaken by Paul Courant and Marilyn Knepp, and so Holbrook's series are continued in their records.

Holbrook's responsibilities were broad; ranging from advising units on annual budget requests and program changes, to coordinating special projects like energy conservation. Toward the end of his tenure, Holbrook pushed the university to adopt a new budgeting model, called Value Centered Management (VCM, also called Responsibility Center Management or RCM). Implemented in 1996, the model was an activity-based budgeting system based on the idea that the costs and benefits of various activities could be most clearly seen where the activities are undertaken--in the schools, colleges and research units. Revenue followed revenue-generating activity and units that engaged in revenue-generating activity were given the fruits of their labor.

The model, as implemented, was criticized by many as being too inflexible and as discouraging collaboration between units. When Nancy Cantor became provost in 1997, she renamed the model the University Budget Model (UBM), and muted its automatic, non-deliberative aspects in favor of more flexibility. Cantor also instituted a multi-year budget planning process. The budget files for 1997-1998 reflect this emphasis on multi-year planning, and also include work of Paul Courant and Marilyn Knepp, as Holbrook transferred his responsibilities to them.

Schools Colleges and Units Budget Files comprise the substantial part of Holbrook's records. Within each yearly flight of records, the budget files for large schools and units are divided into the following categories: Budget, Budget Commitments, Budget Request and, for schools, Enrollment. For smaller units this same information was often combined in one folder. The "Budget" files typically contain records pertaining to disbursements and oversight of the granted budget. The "Budget Commitments" files contain copies the provost's promises of funds for specific items in that fiscal year's budget. The "Budget Request" file contains the unit's proposed budget, Enrollment and Degree Tables (pink), Faculty and Staff Data Tables (white) and Financial Activity Tables (yellow). The "Enrollment" file contain the school's plans and estimates for the next year's enrollment, a figure that was key to determining the total income from tuition and to allocating money to the unit under a value centered management budgeting model.

Holbrook exercised direct supervision of the Office of Financial Aid, and therefore, the budget files for this unit are far richer and more complete than for other units. Important topics for financial aid in the period after 1994 include the merger of the Office of Financial Aid, Undergraduate Admissions and the Registrar, Federal lobbying efforts, and analysis the Indian Tuition Waiver Program.

Within Holbrook's Topical Files there is a substantial amount of material related to the Midwest Universities' Consortium for International Activity (MUCIA). The university joined MUCIA in 1992 and between 1992 and 1997, Holbrook served on its board of directors. His files contain a fairly complete run of agendas and minutes of board of directors' and management committee of board of directors' meetings, audits, reports and correspondence.

The series of Personal Files principally relate to his former teaching activities in the Department of Economics. The Correspondence series includes incoming and outgoing correspondence related to University matters.

scopecontent.p: Robert B. Holmes served as assistant to the vice president 1981-1982, and as assistant vice president 1982-1995. In the early 1990's he assumed the additional responsibilities of executive advisor for M-Quality and director of the Human Resources Development Program in the Human Resources/Affirmative Action division. As assistant vice president Holmes was primarily responsible for overseeing the academic service units (Office of Admissions, Office of Financial Aid, Office of the Registrar, etc.) and minority student services, including recruitment, enrollment and retention.
After leaving the provost's office, he continued on as director of Human Resources Development. In 2002, he became the ombudsman for the University of Michigan.

His records (1968-1995) comprise approximately 66.3 linear feet and are divided into four series, two of which are recurring: Topical Files, Chronological Files, Schools and Colleges Files and M-Quality.

scopecontent.p: As associate vice president from 1984 to 1986, Niara Sudarkasa was charged with leading the university's efforts in minority recruitment and retention. Prior to this appointment Sudarkasa had served as director of the Center for Afro-American and African Studies (CAAS) and was a professor of anthropology. She left the university in 1986 to become the first female president of Lincoln University.

Sudarkasa's records comprise 6 linear feet and consist of three subseries: Personal Files, 1983-1986; Topical Files, 1983-1986; and Office of Minority Affairs Files, 1983-1987. Both the Topical Files and the Office of Minority Affairs Files contain extensive material on the topics of minority recruitment, enrollment and retention. The Topical Files also document Sudarkasa's role in the Tenure Issues Liaison Group.

scopecontent.p: E. Kay Dawson, a lawyer with administrative experience gained at the University of Iowa and Yale, came the University of Michigan in 1989 as assistant to the provost and director of the Office of Academic Human Resources. Her records comprise 7.2 linear feet and consist of budget files for university schools, colleges and other units from 1989/90 to 1992/93, divided in two subseries: Schools and Colleges Budget Files, 1989/90-1992/93, and Units Budget Files, 1989/90-1992/93; and Topical Files. The Topical Files subseries contains some material from Dawson's predecessors, Robin Jacoby and Ruth Hastie, as well from Associate Provost, Mary Ann Swain. Dawson was succeeded by Elizabeth Barry in November, 1996.

scopecontent.p: As associate provost, Susan S. Lipschutz conducted a study of the training of graduate student instructors that resulted in stronger, departmentally based programs. She also examined the experiences of first year students, assisted deans with faculty recruiting and developed programs in support of faculty teaching, leadership skills and career development. She played key roles in the creation of the University Wallenberg Lecture in 1985 and was chair of the selection committee for several years. Four U-M units -- the Office of the Registrar, the Bentley and Clements Libraries, and the Center for the Education of Women -- reported to her.

Lipschutz received her PhD from the University of Michigan in philosophy in 1969 and taught at the University of Denver and Albion College before being recruited by President Harold Shapiro to be his assistant in 1981. In 1986 she became an associate dean of the Rackham School of Graduate Studies under Dean John D'Arms and became the associate provost for academic affairs in 1993, succeeding Mary Ann Swain. She died at the age of 54 in 1997.

Her records comprise 14.5 linear feet and are arranged into six subseries. Her Topical Files, 1977-1998 (bulk 1990-1997) (9.0 lin. ft.), arranged alphabetically by topic, contain evidence of Lipschutz's focus on the study of teaching and learning. Her task forces on the First Year Experience at the University of Michigan and TA Training generated informative studies and reports about the learning environment at the University of Michigan. Her files also reflect her interest in fostering the careers of women faculty and graduate students. Other topics of particular interest include Faculty Governance (see, the various "Faculty" files and "Senate Advisory Committee on University Affairs (SACUA)" file) and the development of technological support systems relating to the admissions and the registrar's offices. Her "Funded Projects" file contains proposals for and evaluations of programs she supported.

The Unit Assessments, 1993-1996 (3 lin. ft.) records contain evidence about evaluation of programs and schools, and consist largely of self-study and long-range planning reports. Lipschutz's Grants, 1995-1997 (1 lin. ft.) series contains proposals, both funded and not funded, for the Service Learning Initiative and the Whitaker Fund. Her Presentations and Remarks 1987-1995 (0.3 lin. ft.) series is arranged in alphabetical order by speech title. Her Supervision of Units, 1977-1999, bulk 1992-1997 (0.7 lin. ft.) series contains materials regarding her oversight of units such as the Communicative Disorders Clinic, the Bentley Historical Library and the Clements Library. Finally, her Assessment, 1991-1996 (0.3 lin. ft.) series contains materials regarding the metrics by which university performance can be evaluated.

Lipschutz's records contain substantial material Lipschutz inherited from her predecessor, Mary Ann Swain. Swain left in 1993 to become Provost of SUN Binghamton. This Staff Records sub-group also includes a Swain series, and many of her other records may be found there.

scopecontent.p: Paul Courant became the provost and executive vice president for academic affairs of the University of Michigan in 2001. His records as provost may be found in the provost's office "Central Files" record group. Before his promotion, however, Courant served as associate provost for academic and budgetary affairs, replacing Robert Holbrook in 1997. His records as associate provost may be found here, in the "Staff Files" record group.

Besides serving in the provost's office, Courant is a professor of economics and public policy, and a faculty associate in the Institute for Social Research. He has served as an Arthur F. Thurnau Professor (1996-1999), as Chair for the Department of Economics and as Director of the Institute for Public Policy Studies. He has also served as a Senior Staff Economist for the Council of Economic Advisors. Courant has authored half a dozen books, and over sixty monographs and papers. He holds a BA in history from Swarthmore College (1968) an MA in economics from Princeton University (1973); and a PhD in Economics for Princeton University (1974).

During his tenure as Associate Provost, he and Marilyn Knepp cooperated in their work. They maintained their records together and the archive preserves their original file structure. Knepp was appointed Assistant Provost for University Budget and Planning in 1997, and was promoted to Associate Vice President for University Budget, Planning and Administration in 2000. Before coming to the Provost's office, she had been director of the Office of Academic Planning and Analysis since 1984.

In addition to budget planning responsibilities, Knepp was responsible for the collection, analysis and reporting of data regarding university operations. She also directed the Office of Budget and Planning, an office created in 1997 from the merger of the existing offices of Budget Administration and Academic Planning and Analysis. Knepp holds a BA from Michigan State University and an MBA from Eastern Michigan University.

The files of Paul Courant and Marilyn Knepp (16.5 lin. ft.) are arranged into two series, which have annual flights: Topical Files (1997-98, 1998-99 and 1999-2000) and Schools, Colleges and Units Budget Files (1999-2000 and 2000-2001). The Topical Files include material relating to budget planning and policy, chronological correspondence, committee agendas, minutes and reports and project files. The Schools, Colleges and Units Budget Files continue the series of Robert Holbrook's records, and contain briefing materials for meetings convened to plan the budgets of each school and administrative unit.

Courant also maintained a separate topical file for his own reference. Those files are designated Paul Courant Topical Files (3 lin. ft.)and cover the period 1998-2002. These files contain materials related to Courant's speeches, including testimony in the Michigan Legislature and presentations to the Board of Regents.

scopecontent.p: Pamela A. Raymond was associate provost for academic and faculty affairs from 1997-2002. She holds three degrees from the University of Michigan, including a PhD in zoology, and after holding an academic appointment at Harvard, joined the medical school faculty here in 1980. Her responsibilities in the Provost's Office included issues regarding promotion, tenure, recruitment and retention, program reviews and new program development. She is a professor in the Department of Cell and Developmental Biology where she studies retinal development and has also served as director of the Neuroscience Program. Her files (3.5 lin. ft.) include some material inherited from her predecessors, Mary Ann Swain and Susan Lipschutz.

scopecontent.p: Katharine B. Soper, was assistant provost for academic and faculty affairs from 1999 to 2002. She received a PhD in French literature from the University of Colorado in 1977 and a JD from the University of Michigan in 1980. Before moving to the provost's office, she worked as a publications attorney at the Institute of Continuing Legal Education. In 2004 she was the Academic Dual Career Program director for the Medical School, College of Engineering and the College of LS&A.

Her records (2.4 lin. ft.) consist of files generated during her work on several projects undertaken in the provost's office, including coordinating the CIC Academic Leadership Seminars, and the Marshall Symposium, updating the Faculty Handbook, and staffing the Media Rights Task Force and the Violence Against Women Task Force.

scopecontent.p: As the provost's chief of staff, Karen Gibbons served as an advisor to the provost; acted as a liaison to the deans, executive officers, and Senate Advisory Committee on University Affairs (SACUA); and managed the provost's staff. She also administered executive searches in the provost's office, and coordinated development-related matters. Gibbons also provided staff support for the Academic Program Group and served as the contact person on publicity matters under the purview of the provost. Gibbons holds her B.A. in human resource administration and began her employment at the University of Michigan in 1970 and in the provost's office in 1990, where she remained until her retirement in 2012.

Gibbons's records comprise 31 linear feet and are divided into seven subseries. Her Committees, 1990-1998 and 1992-2011 subseries contains records she maintained for several important university committees. The provost's key staff regularly met in a group variously called 4+1, 5+1, 6+1, 7+1 and 8+1. The numbers refer to the quantity of the provost's staff in attendance, plus the provost, who is the "one." Generally the associate provosts attended, augmented by the chief of staff and assistant provosts. The records include agendas, supporting materials, and some notes, but no regular minutes.

The Academic Program Group (APG) is a regular meeting of the Provost's staff with the deans and directors of the various schools. For these meetings there are regular minutes, as well as agendas and supporting reports and memoranda. Within the APG records are the records of a retreat on the Future of the Faculty, hosted by Nancy Cantor in October of 1998. Faculty members gathered to discuss issues of faculty governance, non-tenured faculty, and balancing work and family.

The Foundations Fund Raising Committee was made up of selected deans, university officers, and provost staff. It was created to coordinate the university's communications with large foundations, such as the Ford Foundation and the WK Kellogg Foundation. The records are filed by meeting date, and include agendas, reports, and sometimes meeting summaries.

Gibbons' records also include materials on emergency planning at the University, which document plans for dealing with pandemic and flu outbreaks, active shooters, and other emergency situations. Other committees represented in Gibbons' files include several student-administrator committees, miscellaneous Office of Academic Affairs staff meetings, Senate Advisory Committee on University Affairs (SACUA) and the Senate Assembly, and other project and task force committees.

Other series in Gibbons' papers contain her Correspondence Chronological Files, 1992-1996 and Correspondence Targeted Emails, 2004-2013. The targeted emails are correspondence sent out to the entire University population, including students, faculty, and administrators. Her papers also include Budget/Long-Range Planning Files, 1996-1997 , Personnel Files, 1988-2010, including staff searches for the Provost's Office; Reports, 1989-2006, and Topical, 1986-2013.

scopecontent.p: Nancy Cantor served as Provost and Executive Vice President for Academic Affairs from 1997-2001. Her records as provost may be found in the provost's office "Central Files" record group. Cantor's files (1 lin. ft.) consist of records that were not kept as part of the main Central Files record group and are arranged alphabetically by topic heading. The content covers a variety of subjects dating from 1997 to 2000.

scopecontent.p: John B. Godfrey became associate director of the International Institute at the University of Michigan in 1993. He held that position until 1998 when he was appointed Special Assistant to the Provost. In this role, he coordinated the University's 2000 reaccreditation and served on several working groups. In 2001, he was appointed Assistant Dean for International Education reporting to both the dean of Rackham and the vice provost for international affairs. His records consist of 1 lin. ft. of records that include International Files, which document exchange programs and other international activities from his time at the International Institute, Reaccreditation files, Topical Files, and files from the Working Groups. The International Files and Topical Files include some records that pre-date Godfrey's time at the University but were included in his papers.

scopecontent.p: The files of A. Lawrence Fincher and Ralph P. Nichols reflect their involvement in budget affairs and their role liaising with the state government. Because the ownership of the records was not always clear, the records have been joined to create one series within the collection, rather than trying to distinguish Nichols' records from Fincher's. The records (2.75 lin. ft.) are arranged into the Budget Planning Committee series, which includes agendas, minutes, and other meeting materials from the committee, and a Topical Files series, which includes more budget information, project and committee files, and other subject matter. This series also includes information on the Extension Service, particularly surrounding its review in 1980-1981.

A. Lawrence Fincher came to the University of Michigan as an Assistant in Research in 1968, and held positions in the Office of State Relations and Planning, receiving an appointment as Assistant Vice President for State Relations and Planning in 1974. In 1979, Fincher was promoted to Associate Vice President for Analysis and Planning, which oversaw the Office of Academic Planning and Analysis. In this position, Fincher coordinated budget activities within the University, between the Vice President for Academic Affairs and other executive Officers, and coordinated budget affairs between the University and the Regents, Governor's Office, and State Legislature.

Ralph P. Nichols joined the University in 1971, serving in the Registrar's Office at the Dearborn campus. In 1977, he moved to the Ann Arbor campus and worked as coordinator of budget administration. In 1981, he was became an assistant to the Vice President for Academic Affairs, and in 1984 was promoted to an Assistant Vice President for Academic Affairs. As a member of the Office of Academic Affairs, he tracked state legislation on higher education and advised University policy based on that legislation. He died of cancer in 1986.

scopecontent.p: Valerie P. Castle was appointed associate provost for academic and faculty affairs in 2002, replacing Pamela Raymond in the role. Castle held this appointment for one year before returning to the Medical School. Her records are arranged under one Topical Files series, 1992-2003, and include topical files from the units reporting to this position. Units covered include the Bentley Historical Library, Center for the Education of Women, Clements Library, Life Sciences Values and Society Program, and Nichols Arboretum. Topics cover budget and appointments, but also consist of more specialized information, such as building additions or policy discussions. Her files (1 lin. ft.) include some material inherited from her predecessors, Pamela Raymond, Mary Ann Swain, and Susan Lipschutz.

scopecontent.p: Glenda Haskell began working for the University in 1985. In 1988, she moved to the Provost's Office as Coordinator of Academic Programs and Services, later becoming an Assistant Associate Provost. In 1996, she moved to the Rackham Graduate School, serving as assistant to the dean. She returned to the Provost's office in 2002, when she was appointed Assistant Provost, a position she held until 2011 when she retired. Her records group (0.65 lin. ft.) consists of Academic Services Board materials, dating from 1981 to 1997. The Haskell Series also includes files from Ruth Freedman

The Academic Services Board (ASB) was created in 1973 by Vice President Allan F. Smith to provide a sounding board for policy decisions affecting students across multiple units. Members are senior administrators who represent schools, colleges, and central offices engaged in academic support for students. Its mission, outlined in 1991, identifies three functions for the board: to advise the Provost and Deans on areas related to academic services and student affairs; promoting and implementing goals supported by the Board; and to build communication channels between schools, colleges and central offices for sharing information related to academic services and student affairs.

scopecontent.p: In 1993, Linda Gillum became the Assistant Dean for Student Programs for the University of Michigan Medical School and held this position until being appointed Assistant Provost for Academic Affairs in 1999. Reporting to the Senior Vice Provost, Lester Monts, Gillum's responsibilities in the Provost's office pertained to student academic programs and activities, such as overseeing Living Learning Programs and coordinating academic reviews. She also played a significant role on the Undergraduate commission and her records are the most comprehensive documentation from the Provost's office on this project, established by President Bollinger in 2000 to assess undergraduate education at the University and make recommendations for changes. Her records (4.6 lin. ft.) are composed of three series: Committees, which includes documentation on Michigan Learning Communities; Conferences; and Projects, which includes her documentation on the Undergraduate Commission.

scopecontent.p: Janet Weiss joined the Provost's office in 2002 when she was appointed Associate Provost for Academic Affairs, a position that evolved to be responsible for academic affairs, faculty affairs, and academic human resources. She served in this capacity until 2005, when she was appointed Vice Provost for Academic Affairs -- Graduate Studies and Dean of the Rackham Graduate School, responsible for administering graduate programs of the University. Her records form one series, Topical Files (0.6 lin. ft.), dating from her before becoming Dean, and include documentation on several child care initiatives at the University, the merger of the Matthaei Botanical Gardens and Nichols Arboretum, and other subjects. Records pertaining to Weiss's service as Dean of the Rackham Graduate School may be found in the Horace H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies (University of Michigan) records.

His records (0.5 lin. ft.) document his activities relating to the 2010 accreditation process and have been included in the Provost's Staff Files.

scopecontent.p: Sharron Schmidt was the Office Manager for Human Resources and Affirmative Action in the Provost's Office from 2004-2006. In this role, one of her responsibilities was coordinating meetings between the provost and various staff members. Her files are arranged in one series, Provost's Meetings, and consist of 0.65 lin. ft. of records from these one-on-one meetings between the provost and provost's staff members. In 2006, Schmidt became an Assistant to the Provost.

Kathleen (Kati) Bauer and James L. Hilton's records (0.85 lin. ft.) document information technology matters on campus. James Hilton began his career at the University as a faculty member in the Psychology Department. In 2000, Provost Nancy Cantor appointed him a special assistant to the Provost to head up a task force looking into media rights, particularly in regard to digital content. In 2001, he joined the provost's office as the Associate Provost for Academic Information and Instructional Technology, serving as the Interim University Librarian for a year in 2005. He left the University in 2006 to serve as Vice President and Chief Information Officer at the University of Virginia, but returned to the University of Michigan and the Provost's Office in 2013 with appointments as professor in the School of Information, Dean of Libraries and University Librarian, and Vice Provost for Digital Educational Initiatives.

Kati Bauer began working for the University in 1976, and moved into technology related roles in 1988. Between 1997 and 2001, she held various roles under the University's chief information officer, JosÃ©-Marie Griffiths. In 2001, she became Assistant to the Associate Provost for Information Technology, the post being held at the time by James L. Hilton. Bauer held this position until 2010, when she moved to the office of Vice Provost of International Affairs. In 2013, she rejoined Hilton, working under him in his role as Dean of Libraries.

The records of Kathleen Bauer date mainly from Hilton's work in the Provost's Office as Associate Provost for Academic Information and Bauer's service as assistant. It is not always clear which participant created the records; therefore the records have been arranged jointly under Hilton and Bauer. These records relate to matters pertaining to IT infrastructure, issues, and policy development affecting campus, including a number of files related to copyright and media rights.

As well as records created jointly with Hilton, a series of records exists in which Bauer is the sole creator. The Kathleen Bauer records (0.4 lin. ft.) are similar in nature to the Kati Bauer and James Hilton records, documenting matters relating to campus IT, and are arranged in one Topical Files series and differ primarily in ownership.

scopecontent.p: Marilyn Knepp also maintained files on her responsibilities outside of budgeting. These files (8.1 lin. ft.) have been arranged into two series: Committees and Topical Files. The Committees series contains minutes, agendas, and other materials for various committees and projects Knepp served on, including the Administrative Data Delivery Advisory Group (ADDAG), the Committee on Health Insurance Premium Design (CHIPD), the Enrollment Working Group (EWG), and the University Budget and Finance Group (UBFG). Projects include MPathways and the Classification System Project, which focused on the re-classification of job titles within the University.

scopecontent.p: In 2004, Philip J. Hanlon was appointed as Associate Provost for Academic and Budgetary Affairs, taking on the responsibilities previously belonging to Paul Courant in this position. Hanlon joined the University of Michigan Mathematics Department in 1986. He became a Thurnau Professor in 1992, and the Donald J. Lewis Professor of Mathematics in 2001 and was founder and the first executive director of the Michigan Math and Science Scholars. From 2001-2004, he served as Associate Dean for Planning and Finance in the College of Literature, Science and the Arts after which he became an associate provost, then Vice Provost in 1997. In 2010, he was selected as Provost for Academic Affairs, a position he occupied until 2013, when he became President of Dartmouth College. His records as provost may be found in the provost's office "Central Files" record group.

During his term as Associate Provost for Academic and Budgetary Affairs. Hanlon worked with several other staff members on budget matters. Marilyn Knepp worked with Hanlon for the fiscal year 2007, before moving to the Rackham Graduate School. The Philip Hanlon and Marilyn Knepp files (4.0 lin. ft.) also include master files for the University Press. The following two years, FY 2008 and FY 2009, budget planning was managed by Hanlon, Teresa Sullivan (Provost), and Anne Berens, Assistant Vice Provost. The Philip Hanlon, Teresa Sullivan, and Anne Berens files measure 5.85 lin. ft. For fiscal year 2010, this work was handled by Hanlon and Berens. Files for this year measure 2.5 lin. ft. Budgets for fiscal year 2011 were managed by Philip Hanlon and Teresa Sullivan, and measure 1 lin. ft. The Philip Hanlon, Martha E. Pollack, and Anne Berens files measure 5 linear feet and consist of budget materials for 2011-2012. Martha Pollack served as Vice Provost for Academic and Budgetary Affairs from 2010-2013. For 2012-2013, Philip Hanlon, Lori Haskins, and Ron Fitzgerald handled the Schools and Colleges budget files (3.5 lin. ft.). Lori Haskins served as Assistant Vice Provost for Academic and Budgetary Affairs in 2011, and Ron Fitzgerald served as Assistant Vice Provost for Academic and Budgetary Affairs from 2011-2012. Philip Hanlon, Martha E. Pollack, Lori Haskins, and Ron Fitzgerald managed Executive Officer budget files from 2012-2013 (2 lin. ft.), and Philip Hanlon and Martha E. Pollack handled budget files for Academic Affairs Units (1 lin. ft.) in 2012-2013.

Starting with FY 2007, budget files are arranged in three subseries: Schools and Colleges Budget, Executive Officers Budget, and Unit Budget Files. This arrangement reflects the organization of the files as they were received by the Bentley. The content, however, is the same as that included in previous budget years.

As well as budget files, there is also a series of Committees Files belonging strictly to Hanlon documenting his activities on committees related to his work in budgetary affairs and in the Provost's office. In addition, there is a series of Philip Hanlon Town Hall Meetings from Fall 2009 to Spring 2010, as well as a series on UM's Financial Position from 2009-2010. The Philip Hanlon records include 1.65 lin. ft. of minutes, agendas, and other materials from the various committees Hanlon was involved in and span the years 2005-2006. There is also an additional 0.3 lin. ft. of records detailing Hanlon's town hall meetings and UM's financial position from 2009-2010. His records as provost may be found in the provost's office "Central Files" record group.

scopecontent.p: Brian Konz began working for the University of Michigan at the English Language Institute, where he did accounting. In 2007, he became a Financial Specialist in the Provost's Office, a position he held until 2012, when he became a business administrator for fiscal matters at the National Center for Institutional Diversity. His brief records series of Financial Files (0.1 lin. ft.) contributes information on financial controls and the Provost's budget.

In 2000, John L. King came to the University of Michigan as Dean of the School of Information. In 2006, he was appointed Vice Provost for Academic Information, a position that worked with IT infrastructure, the libraries, and other knowledge resources. In 2010, he became Vice Provost for Strategy, and in 2011, he returned to the faculty full-time. His records (0.3 lin. ft.) consist of Correspondence, comprised of incoming and outgoing correspondence, and Topical Files, which include files on cost reduction at the University and information on the Michigan Virtual University (MVU).

As well as her contributions to the Budget Files, Anne Berens has a small series of records (0.2 lin. ft) documenting her involvement with the University Press. In 2006, the University Press was facing a financial crisis and Berens was part of the committee looking into the situation and developing a plan for the Press's future. Berens began working for the University of Michigan in 2004 as a manager in the Office of Financial Analysis. She became an Assistant Vice Provost in 2006. From 2008-2011, Berens served as Assistant Vice Provost for Academic and Budgetary Affairs. A small series of records (0.7 lin. ft) document budget materials under her leadership in this position from 2009-2010.

scopecontent.p: Stephanie Riegle became a Senior Project Manager for Academic and Budgetary Affairs in the Provost's Office in 2006, where she worked on projects relating to campus space and facilities, receiving the title of Assistant Associate Provost in 2007. In 2008, she joined the provost's senior staff as Assistant Vice Provost for Academic and Budgetary Affairs, then becoming Acting Chief of Staff and Assistant Vice Provost of Academic and Budgetary Affairs. With the retirement of Karen Gibbons, Riegle assumed the role of Chief of Staff of the Provost's office. In this capacity, Riegle advises and provides staff support for the Provost and the Academic Program Group, liaises with other administrative and executive officers, oversees the office staff, and is involved with development and publicity matters.

Stephanie Riegle's files (5.2 lin. ft.) cover the span of her activities in the Provost's Office and are arranged in four series. The Space files relate to space issues on campus, such as renovations, new construction, and the financial implications of these projects. The Multidisciplinary Learning and Team Teaching series consists of records from the initiative to support opportunities for interdisciplinary learning on campus. The Academic Program Group (APG) series includes minutes, agendas, and other materials from APG meetings, and the final series of Topical Files consists of files on a variety of subjects. The Riegle series includes some Karen Gibbons materials

scopecontent.p: Catherine Shaw first started working in the Provost's office as a part-time speechwriter. In 2004, she became a full-time member of staff, working as a Special Assistant to the Provost. In this role, she conducted research and provided administrative support for faculty-related areas, was involved in policy development, and handled other projects for the Provost. One of these projects was participating in preparations for President Mary Sue Coleman's visit to China in 2005. It is material from this project that forms her records series, China files (0.3 lin. ft.). In 2006, her title was changed to Assistant Provost, and in 2008, Shaw became Assistant Vice Provost for Academic and Faculty Affairs, contributing her research and writing skills to issues surrounding higher education policy and university affairs.

Lester P. Monts came to the University of Michigan from the University of California -- Santa Barbara in 1993 to assume the position of Vice Provost for Academic and Multicultural Affairs1 and a professor of music. In 1998, he became Associate Provost for Academic and Multicultural Affairs, a position that was retitled Senior Vice Provost for Academic Affairs in 2001. He held this position until 2014, when he returned to the School of Music as a full-time faculty member. In 2002, he was appointed to serve as senior counselor to the president for the arts, diversity and undergraduate affairs.

As Senior Vice Provost, Monts established awards honoring contributions to diversity, including the Harold R. Johnson Diversity Service Award, the Shirley Verrett Award, and the Percy Bates/Don Deskins Award for Academic and Athletic Excellence. He also established several centers and programs, including the Center for Educational Outreach (CEO), the Center for World Performance Studies, Global Intercultural Experiences for Undergraduates (GIEU), the Council on Global Engagement, the Office of New Student Programs (ONSP), the National Center for Institutional Diversity (NCID), and the Confucius Institute.

In his roles as Associate and then Senior Vice Provost, Monts was involved with faculty tenure and promotion review, enrollment management, fiscal operations, undergraduate affairs, and diversity affairs. Units reporting to him included: the Office of Undergraduate Admissions, Office of Financial Aid, Office of the Registrar, Office of Academic Multicultural Initiatives, Office of Examinations and Evaluations, Office of New Student Programs, Arts at Michigan, Center for Research on Learning and Teaching, and the ROTC programs. Other units that reported to the Senior Vice Provost at various times included the Center for Educational Outreach, the Detroit Center, the National Center for Institutional Diversity, the Arts Consortium, the Confucius Institute, and Institutional Equity.

Monts also served on the board of trustees for both Ann Arbor Summer Festival, Inc. and the University Musical Society. In 2005 he was appointed a Thurnau professor. Academically, Monts is a leading scholar on the music and culture of the Guinea coast region of West Africa, focusing his research on the Vai people of Liberia. He has received honorary professorships from six Chinese universities and in 2010 was inducted into the Hall of Distinction as a Distinguished Alumnus at Arkansas Tech, his alma mater.

Records from Monts in the Staff Files were accessioned as part of other Provost's Office transfers. The majority of the records were created after his appointment as Associate Provost in 1998, with a few exceptions. Researchers using the Monts files may also want to consult the Vice President for Academic and Multicultural Affairs (VPAMA) records collection, which contains documentation on Monts' service in this position as well as some records as Associate Provost which overlap with materials found in the Provost's Office Staff Files. The series measures 43 linear feet.

Lester Monts files consist of seven series: Office of the Associate Provost Files, General Files, Unit Files, Budget Files, Chronological Files, Committees, and Awards. The arrangement reflects the original organization of the records when accessioned. While there are some records from Monts' service as Vice Provost, the bulk of the records date after 1998, when he became Associate Provost.

scopecontent.p: The Unit Files series contains records for some of the units reporting to Monts. These records contain information similar to that found in the General Files and corresponding files may exist in the General Files for years not represented in the Unit Files series. The Unit Files, however, include documentation that goes beyond what is typically represented in the General Files. Units represented include Admissions, the Center for Research on Learning and Teaching (CRLT), Financial Aid, the international Institute, the National Center for institutional Diversity (NCID), and the ROTC. The CRLT and International Institute files include records that were not available through their respective collections and so have been retained here. Information on the ROTC is also sparse elsewhere, making this series a useful source of documentation.

scopecontent.p: The General Files series is the main records group, documenting the work carried out by Monts in fulfilling his responsibilities as Associate, and then Senior Vice Provost as well as his professional activities. These records are arranged by academic year, with subjects arranged alphabetically under each year, starting with 1998/1999. Later years contain UMS board meeting materials and SACUA materials that were not available through their respective collections. There is also a Pre-1998 run that incorporates material prior to Monts' appointment as Associate Provost. For more records from this time period, researchers may consult the Vice Provost for Academic and Multicultural Affairs records collection.

The Committees series consists of materials from three committees that Monts participated in: Academic Services Board (ASB), the Council on a Multicultural University (COMU), and the Undergraduate Council. The Council on a Multicultural University was created in 1990 to assist in achieving the goals of the Michigan Mandate relating to diversity. The Undergraduate Council was formed to implement the recommendations of the President's Commission on the Undergraduate Experience, or the Undergraduate Commission. As with other records series, the Committees series may overlap with records in Monts' General Files.

scopecontent.p: The final series in Monts' files is the Awards series. This series documents awards and funding given to faculty members, with the exception of the Rhodes/Marshall/Mitchell Scholars, which is awarded to graduate students to study in the United Kingdom. Candidates are nominated by their universities and compete at the national level. Faculty awards in the series include the following: discretionary funding, which provides funding to faculty from the Senior Vice Provost's office; the Faculty Award for Research and Creative Projects (FARCP); Faculty Career Development Awards (FCDA), which support recipients in pursuing research and scholarly activities by providing financial resources for travel, materials, and other equipment; the Harold Johnson Diversity Service award, established in 1996 to honor faculty that contribute to diversity on campus; the King/Chavez/Parks award, funded by the state of Michigan to increase representation of minorities in the faculty pool for higher education; the Lecturers' Professional Development Fund (LPDF), awarded through the Center for Research on Learning and Teaching, which supports improvements to teaching and curriculum; presidential professors, a program established to facilitate visits from distinguished artists and scholars to the campus, with particular interest in minority guests; and the Thurnau Professor award. More information and documentation on Thurnau professorships may be found in other collections, including the Provost's Supplemental Files.

The Awards series is arranged alphabetically within each year. The exception to this is the Rhodes/Marshall/Mitchell awards, which is arranged by year and alphabetically as appropriate. Materials on student applicants is placed alphabetically under students, then arranged by year. The years are those in which the students applied, the award being granted the following year. For discretionary funding and the Faculty Career Development Award, only files reflecting faculty research and campus academics were retained in the collection as documentation of faculty activity at the University. The Faculty Awards for Research and Creative Projects span the years 1993-1996; for later years, researchers should consult the Vice Provost for Academic and Multicultural Affairs records.
